levels.title: the stuff
levels.description: Can you believe Ryan uses Bing?

levels.title: xxdme
levels.description: This cat has the key, but seems unwilling to share it with you.
levels.hint: xxd, hexedit, and bvi are all reasonable tools to try. Confused? Perhaps Google knows.

levels.title: Here Goes!
levels.description: Have you guys every watched Gravity Falls? It's a great show with tons of cryptography sprinkled throughout. I got this odd photo in the mail from Uncle Stan, we were working on his hot air balloon last week. What does it mean?

levels.title: Free Points!
levels.description: Check the hint for free points!

levels.title: Two-Time Pad
levels.description: My new encryption (two-time pad, under patent review) is twice as secure as one time pads. I am so certain about the security of my new scheme that I am releasing the encrypted versions of my two most secret pictures.
levels.hint: The images were encrypted with the same key K as such: encrypted_pixels[i] = pixels[i] XOR K[i].

levels.title: EBG13
levels.description:
Decrypt the ciphertext:

Pbjneqf qvr znal gvzrf orsber gurve qrnguf; gur inyvnag arire gnfgr bs qrngu ohg bapr. Sbe gur inyvnag, urer yvrf gur synt: nexakvosvuclcebs

levels.title: Southern Cross
levels.description:
Wow, what's this, Soos?

It's the Confederacy's cipher disk with a help of which southerners encrypted their messages.

How does it work?

Look, Dipper. We need to encode the phrase MABLE EATS SPRINKLES. We don't need any spaces so just delete them. We get MABLEEATSSPRINKLES. Then we have too choose a key. Let it be GRAVITY. And let's go !!!

<Watch the YouTube video>

You see, we've encrypted the phrase and here it is RBZTXYZJSKZBLQCEN

Cool!

Now I'll encode a famous story and you'll try to decode it. By the way, it's much more interesting to read the whole story over, isn't it?

....

That's complicated. Maybe I have to find a key at first. I'd better look for someone who is able to solve this...

Don't forget to reach to the end of the text! The ending is greatly important.
levels.hint: See if you can find a way to crack the encrypted text online. Statistical analysis is your friend.

levels.title: Gametime
levels.description:
Guess what time it is! That’s right! Gametime! Wowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww!!!!!!!!!!!!

Author: Brad Antoniewicz

levels.title: core1
levels.description: core1.bin crashed while reading a keyfile and generated a core dump core1. Can you recover the key?
levels.hint: You COULD debug it, but do you really want to?

levels.title: readasm
levels.description:
At the end of this sequence of instructions, how many bytes separate esp and the stored return address on the program's stack? Assume that we called this function using standard 32-bit x86 calling conventions.

804847c functioname:
804847c: push %ebp
804847d: mov %esp,%ebp
804847f: sub $0x60,%esp
8048482: movl $0x0,0x4(%esp)
804848a: movl $0x8048580,(%esp)

Answer in *decimal*
levels.hint: You may find this reference (http://codearcana.com/posts/2013/05/21/a-brief-introduction-to-x86-calling-conventions.html) informative.
